title: Earth Day 2024: 8 ways to live more sustainably
intro: Climate change calls for long-term, systemic solutions, but that doesn't mean we can't all strive to live more sustainably. Life Kit is here with solutions from your kitchen to your closet.

transcript.author: ANDEE TAGLE, HOST
transcript.text: This is NPR's LIFE KIT. It's Earth week. And let's not dance around it - being an Earthling isn't easy these days. Flash floods and devastating earthquakes, extreme heat and shrinking ecosystems and rising sea levels and raging forest fires - no matter where you are in the planet, the effects of the climate crisis are vast and real. They're a constant source of big worry and fear for most and big struggles for many. It can be easy to feel hopeless amid so many compounding disasters or frustrated by the snail-slow pace of change. And it's true - individual action has its limits, but it's not too late to come together and make a real difference.

transcript.author: ANDEE TAGLE, HOST
transcript.text: According to a recent report from the U.N., the world can still avoid the most extreme dangers of the climate crisis if, collectively, nations can work together to embrace the solutions and technology needed to cut emissions rapidly. Again, to be clear, we're not putting solving the climate crisis on you, listener. That's done by governments and policies. But we know that our decisions matter. Using less energy at home, choosing to live and work in walkable areas, composting, upcycling - all of these individual choices can add up and help tip the scales towards progress. And the good news is there are endless ways to start.

transcript.author: ANDEE TAGLE, HOST
transcript.text: I'm Andee Tagle, one of the producers of this show, and in this episode of LIFE KIT, our team is here to help you get going on your green living with tips from some of our favorite sustainability episodes. We've got a list of ideas as big and green as your favorite tree, so don't you leaf.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Up first, producer Sylvie Douglis. Hey, Sylvie.

transcript.author: SYLVIE DOUGLIS, BYLINE
transcript.text: Hey, Andee. So my tips are about food waste. We all know it's a huge contributing factor to the climate crisis. But I learned from our episode about combating food waste that 8% of greenhouse gas emissions come from wasted food, and roughly half of food waste occurs during the consumption stage, meaning waste from, like, food service, restaurants and households.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: That is a lot.

transcript.author: DOUGLIS
transcript.text: Yeah, it's something we all know that we can work on by being more thoughtful and realistic when grocery shopping, or for me, it's really just resisting the urge to order takeout when I've got fresh groceries just waiting to be used. But there's a few tips that I want to share, and they both have to do with one kitchen appliance. Can you guess what it is?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Could it be the fridge or the freezer?

transcript.author: DOUGLIS
transcript.text: Yes, it's the freezer.

transcript.author: TIFFANY DERRY
transcript.text: Make the freezer your best friend (laughter).

transcript.author: DOUGLIS
transcript.text: So that's Tiffany Derry. She's a chef in Texas, and she's a huge proponent of using your freezer to cut down on waste.

transcript.author: DERRY
transcript.text: I freeze anything that I'm not going to use quickly. Berries, pineapple - I mean, all of those fruits are things that people buy already. Why not get it while it's in the peak of season and then pop it in a bag and just have it in your freezer ready to go? You know it's delicious. You know what time of the year it was brought in.

transcript.author: DOUGLIS
transcript.text: And freezing food is healthy, too. Freezing stuff locks in flavor and nutrients. And it's better than letting groceries languish in the fridge.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Ugh, my poor groceries. So many have languished. And I hear you have another freezer tip up your sleeve.

transcript.author: DOUGLIS
transcript.text: Yeah, my freezer is not that big, but I'm putting it to work with another way that I tackle food waste, which is composting. So I started composting in the past couple years, but I live in an apartment and don't have any outdoor space, so I compost in my freezer. And then once a week, I take this sort of alien-looking popsicle of frozen peels and pits and rinds and coffee grounds, and I drop it off at my community garden. And it's kind of fun 'cause you get to meet other people in your neighborhood doing the same thing, and you get to spy on their eating habits, too.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: I would not be mad at that. And bonus - if it's frozen, it doesn't smell, right? Because I know that's what a lot of people have a problem with when it comes to composting.

transcript.author: DOUGLIS
transcript.text: Yeah, no smell. And then it gets turned into rich, healthy soil. And last summer, they gave me a baggie of the soil from our community garden to bring home and use in my house plants.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Wow. A full loop. I love it.

transcript.author: DOUGLIS
transcript.text: Yeah, it's great. But I've also learned about some ways to compost that rely less on the trusty freezer. There's vermicomposting, which is where you take a big sort of five-gallon bin, order some worms online and compost indoors. And then there's also the Japanese method of bokashi, which is essentially fermenting your food scraps. So there's a lot to look into.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Worms and bacteria - what fun. Thanks, Sylvie.

transcript.author: DOUGLIS
transcript.text: Thanks, Andee.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Up next, producer Audrey Nguyen. Hey, Audrey.

transcript.author: AUDREY NGUYEN, BYLINE
transcript.text: Hey, Andee.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: What have you got for us today?

transcript.author: NGUYEN
transcript.text: My tip comes from an episode I worked on last summer with Rebecca Davis about plastic. I got to say, when I sit down and think about the plastics problem for too long, I get really overwhelmed. Like, I know we're not going to recycle our way out of the climate crisis, so I've definitely questioned how much my actions, like, as an individual can make an impact. But working on the piece helped me recognize on a very emotional level that some action is better than none.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: I feel you. Overwhelmed is the right word, for sure. There are so many plastic products in our life. They all have different numbers. I just - I don't even know where to start.

transcript.author: NGUYEN
transcript.text: Well, in the episode, Rebecca interviewed Yvette Arellano, the founder of an environmental justice organization called Fenceline Watch. The group is based in my hometown, Houston, Texas, and they advocate for marginalized communities that are concerned about the long-term effects of pollution from petrochemical plants.

transcript.author: REBECCA DAVIS, BYLINE
transcript.text: Why is it so important to use less plastic, anyway?

transcript.author: YVETTE ARELLANO
transcript.text: Because it affects children's lives. It increases cancer rates. And it hurts people. You know, why would we want to participate in something that is actively oppressing and hurting people's health?

transcript.author: NGUYEN
transcript.text: Before working on the episode, I hadn't fully appreciated the relationship between fossil fuels, plastics and public health.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Yeah, actively oppressing and hurting people. Wow. What more can we do about this, Audrey?

transcript.author: NGUYEN
transcript.text: So we've all heard the phrase recycle, reduce and reuse. And lots of folks say we should put more emphasis on the reducing and reusing part of that instead of just maintaining the same level of consumption and just recycling. Now, full disclosure - I've gotten a lot worse about using single-use plastic during the pandemic with, like, all of the takeout I've been eating.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: You're not the only one, I'm sure.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Also guilty.

transcript.author: NGUYEN
transcript.text: So I've been thinking about something another expert did.

transcript.author: SHILPI CHHOTRAY
transcript.text: What I started doing was literally taking an inventory of all of the plastic in our apartment.

transcript.author: NGUYEN
transcript.text: That's Shilpi Chhotray. When we talked to her, she was the global communications lead from Break Free From Plastic. Shilpi tallied up the different types of plastic packaging she had in her home, which gets me to the tip I'm here to share today. Do an audit of the plastics in your home. It will help you understand not only how much plastic you're using but also how you're using it. So you can make an actionable plan about how to cut back.

transcript.author: CHHOTRAY
transcript.text: It was a wakeup call for us because a lot of the plastic that we thought could be recycled, we learned they're actually not getting picked up by curbside recycling.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Oof. Auditing the whole house sounds like a huge undertaking. Imagine you want to go room by room, right? I know there are a lot of plastic bottles in my bathroom right now, for example.

transcript.author: NGUYEN
transcript.text: That's exactly right. Go room by room. Take note of all the plastic, and don't forget to check the trash. Shilpi says that the two main areas you're probably going to see the most plastic are in your kitchen and, like you noticed yourself, Andee, the bathroom. After you finish your inventory, think about ways you can reduce your use of those plastics.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: OK. Are there any sustainable swaps that you've tried, any that you recommend, any favorites, Audrey?

transcript.author: NGUYEN
transcript.text: I think one of the easiest things I've done is switch from body wash to a bar of soap. I also recently discovered that there's a shop down the street from me that lets you bring in your own containers and buy hand soap and dried goods. So I'm going to check that out later this week. I also tried switching over to toothpaste tabs at some point, but my partner hated the texture and, like, hard vetoed that swap. So those are out.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: I am Team Veto on that. We tried.

transcript.author: NGUYEN
transcript.text: (Laughter).

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: I can't - I just - I don't - I can't do it. But definitely lots to consider this Earth Day or perhaps plastic-free July. Thanks, Audrey.

transcript.author: NGUYEN
transcript.text: Thanks.

transcript.author: MEGHAN KEANE, BYLINE
transcript.text: Hey, Andee.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Hey, Meghan, managing producer of LIFE KIT. What do you have today?

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: Well, Andee, before we get started, I just want to say that's a really nice top you have on today. How many times do you think you've worn it?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Oh, thanks, M.K. This old thing - I picked this up last spring maybe and have just brought it back now that the weather's a little warmer. So maybe 10 times.

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: OK. All right. The reason I ask you - it's not to shame you, I promise, but rather to get us thinking about how often we really wear the clothes we have in our closet. You know, trends move so quickly these days, and I'm on TikTok enough to know that the youths are going to make fun of anything that I own that was in fashion before, like, the year 2016.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: (Laughter).

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: And it's very tempting to just buy the cheap stuff and, you know, wear what's ever the microtrend right now.

transcript.author: SYMPHONY CLARKE
transcript.text: People are so quick to - oh, it doesn't fit anymore. Trash. Oh, this doesn't look good anymore. Trash.

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: (Laughter) That's...

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Guilty.

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: ...Symphony Clarke. She goes by The Thrift Guru on TikTok.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: I know her. She was in our sustainable closet episode.

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: Sure was.

transcript.author: CLARKE
transcript.text: We live in this generation now where people won't even get caught dead seeing people, like, wearing the same outfit twice. That's the lifespan of their clothing. Once a picture is taken, it's done.

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: Now, I'm not quite at that level, but I have been known just to buy a new piece of clothing simply because I wanted it and not because I needed it.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: And that leads to a bigger issue, right? Because so much of used clothing just ends up in landfills.

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: Yes. And it's estimated that only 1% of clothing actually gets recycled.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Wow.

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: You know, making textiles is a very water-intensive process, not to mention human labor issues. I mean, there is just so much wrong with how clothing gets manufactured. It's overwhelming. But as a consumer, you can think about, you know, buying more thrifted clothes. And this is my tip for you - before you buy, ask yourself this question.

transcript.author: CLARKE
transcript.text: When you go shopping, when you look at an item, will you wear this item at least 30 times? And that alone will get people thinking, like, what? Why would I want to wear something 30 times? That's really the key. You want to actually extend the lifespan of clothing.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: That's a really nice mindset shift. You know, you're creating a speed bump for yourself to see if this is something you're going to keep out of a landfill. Plus, think about money, right? Cost per wear.

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: Exactly. And I would even go further and recommend people think about a 60- or a 90-wear test. If you get a stain on it, how are you going to take care for that piece of clothing so you just don't toss it out? So my tip is to think of your clothes not as disposable and use this 30-day rule before you bring something new into your closet.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: I love it. I'm going to see how many wears I can get out of this shirt now. Thanks, M.K.

transcript.author: KEANE
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.author: BECK HARLAN, BYLINE
transcript.text: Hi, Andee.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Beck, our wonderful visuals editor. Hello.

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: Hello. So I want to kick us off with a little trivia.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Oh, gosh.

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: You ready?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Go for it.

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: OK. What percent of greenhouse gas emissions in the U.S. would you attribute to buildings?

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: OK. I have had to guess a lot in this episode. Am I on a secret game show? OK. What percent would I attribute to buildings? Maybe 10%?

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: Oh, Andee, I'm sorry...

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: (Laughter).

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: ...You're not going to win that brand-new electric car. No, no. Not a bad guess, but it's more.

transcript.author: DONNEL BAIRD
transcript.text: Buildings in the United States are responsible for 30% of greenhouse gas emissions across the country. If you want to do something about climate change, your home is among the most important places to look.

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: That's Donnel Baird, the CEO of BlocPower. And while we don't have control over all buildings, if we start where we do have some control - our homes - there's definitely something that we can do to reduce emissions, even if you're renting. So in a lot of states, if you pay your utility bill, you may have some control over the source of your electricity. Here's Baird again.

transcript.author: BAIRD
transcript.text: The very first thing you can do is you can call your local utility company, and you can let them know that you want your electricity to come from 100% clean energy.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Wow. This is huge, Beck. I had no idea this was an option for renters.

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: Yeah, it's exciting. It's called consumer choice. And while your utility company stays the same, you can sometimes choose the supplier of your energy. So I rented a room in a group house in D.C. for many years, and my housemates and I did this. Our utility company was Pepco, but we had an option to choose who actually supplied that energy. All in all, it took about 30 minutes to make the switch, and then boom - every month, you're just automatically getting electricity from clean energy.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Wow. This is a great tip, Beck. But 30 minutes, is it that easy? I'm assuming you want to look at rates and read all the fine print, of course.

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: For sure. Yes, absolutely, do your due diligence. But in terms of environmental impact for time spent, this is a really good return on investment.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Yeah, absolutely. Sounds like a super easy and efficient way to reduce your carbon footprint.

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: Yeah. So just call your utility company or set aside a little time with Michael Google (ph) to see if this is an option for you.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: (Laughter).

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: And I know that spending time on the phone with your utility company is no one's favorite pastime. But I'm very bad at life admin, and I promise that this is actually pretty painless. And if you find out that it's not an option for you, there are tons of other ideas about how to green your home in our episode, from switching out your light bulbs to insulating your windows - really sexy stuff...

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: (Laughter).

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: ...Here. I know. But it does make a difference. So just search LIFE KIT, climate change and home, and it should be one of the first results.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Yes, please. And there's a lot more where that came from.

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: The planet will thank you, and so will we.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: Yes, we will. Thanks Beck.

transcript.author: HARLAN
transcript.text: Thank you.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: And that brings us to the end of our episode. We hope we inspired you to start being more sustainable in your corner of the planet. But if these tips don't do quite enough for you, don't forget about the two very powerful tools already in your toolbox - your voice and your vote. Run for local office. Write to your politicians and demand more climate action. Tell your favorite companies what green practices you want to see from them or divest from ones that don't have them. Amplify the work of climate scientists on your social media or voice your support for sustainability bills. We can all make a big impact with our words, our wallets and the ballot box. The time is now.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: You can find the full version of all the episodes we talked about today at npr.org/lifekit. And if you love LIFE KIT and want more, subscribe to our newsletter at npr.org/lifekitnewsletter. And now, a random tip from one of our listeners.

transcript.author: CHRIS MAHAFFEY
transcript.text: My name is Chris Mahaffey (ph). I make a lot of hummus, but cleaning up after hummus is actually not that fun. So what I've started doing is putting soap and water into the blender and pressing pulse multiple times to get it cleaned on its own. That way, you pour the water right out, do a little scrubbing, and you're fine.

transcript.author: TAGLE
transcript.text: If you've got a good tip, leave us a voicemail at 202-216-9823, or email us a voice memo at lifekit@npr.org. This episode of LIFE KIT was produced by Sylvie Douglis with engineering support from the fabulous team at NPR West - Robert Rodriguez (ph), Gilly Moon and Maggie Luthar. Meghan Keane is the managing producer. Beth Donovan is the senior editor. Our production team also includes Audrey Nguyen, Clare Marie Schneider and Mansee Khurana. Our digital editor is Dalia Mortada, and our visuals editor is Beck Harlan. I'm Andee Tagle. Thanks for listening.
